With Graves Eye Disease, the autoimmune response (antibodies) attacks the muscles behind the eyes, causing fat to be deposited in the muscles.  When enough fat builds up, there is no place for the eye to go except out the front of the socket, because the rest of the eyeball is surrounded by the bony orbit.  Sometimes the pressure is so great, the muscles press on the optic nerve which causes vision problems (and needs to be treated right away), sometimes the fat deposits cause the muscles to pull the eye out of alignment, causing double vision.Orbital decompression removes some of the orbital wall (bony decompression) or some of the fat (fat decompression), or both.  Often additional surgeries are needed to correct double vision and eyelid retraction (where the upper and/or lower lids pull back due to the muscle problems and expose more of the white of the eye than normal).There are blood tests to see if a person has the antibodies that causes Graves Eye Diseas (also called Throid eye diseas or thyrotoxic exophthalmos).  Also, a CT scan will show how involved the eye muscles are.  Usually, a surgeon will not do orbital decompression surgery until the thyroid levels are stable (if thyroid problems are present).I hope your husband just is having after effects of the cataract surgery or the glaucoma problems.  I don't have any experience with either of those conditions.  I have dealt with Graves and Graves Eye disease for about 3 years now, but am on the road back to "normal".  Good luck to you and your husband.
